title: How To Deal With A Partner Who's Always Working
summary: Co-working is a way of working that brings together people from different companies and industries in a shared space to exchange ideas and collaborate. Here are some tips for dealing with someone who is always working. Remember that your partner’s job can be stressful, and it's important for them to decompress when they come home. Set boundaries and don’t be a martyr, even if your partner is working a lot, you still have to do your fair share around the house and with the kids.

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Working too much is a problem many people struggle with \u2014 but it\u2019s even more challenging when you\u2019re in a relationship with someone who has the same work ethic. If your partner usually leaves for work before you even get out of bed, or isn\u2019t home until after you\u2019re already in bed, things can get tricky.
Working from home, flexible hours and remote working are all buzzwords in today\u2019s labor market. Companies are becoming increasingly aware that it isn\u2019t just about how much time employees spend at the desk but also about what they achieve during that time. A Gallup poll found that telecommuting or working from home is growing in popularity among professionals across most industries. Working remotely makes it easier to find jobs, negotiate schedules and live without a commute.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

Many also provide additional services such as training and networking events, administrative assistance and even catering."),mdx("p",null,"Co-working is the perfect arrangement if your partner works remotely and you\u2019re at home with a little one. Remember that your partner\u2019s job can be stressful, and it\u2019s important for them to decompress when they come home. You don\u2019t want to make them feel guilty or resentful if you\u2019re always prying."),mdx("p",null,"Try not to take it personally - Your partner\u2019s workload might not have anything to do with you. They might be stressed, worried or have other factors that are causing them to work more than they normally would. Remember, trying to change someone\u2019s behaviour is a difficult task. It\u2019s important that you don\u2019t take their extended hours at the office personally."),mdx("p",null,"Ask them if they\u2019re feeling stressed - If you notice that your partner is working more and longer than they normally would, ask them if they\u2019re feeling stressed. Even if your partner is working more hours than usual, you still have to do your fair share around the house and with the kids. Don\u2019t be a martyr, and don\u2019t feel guilty for asking for help. It\u2019s important that you don\u2019t get resentful and start resenting your partner just because they\u2019re working more."),mdx("h2",null,"Set boundaries and don\u2019t be a martyr"),mdx("p",null,"Even if you\u2019re in a relationship with someone who works a lot, you still need to set boundaries. If your partner is always working, it might be a good idea to set certain times of the day or certain days when they have to stop. If they\u2019re always working and you\u2019re always cleaning the house and taking care of the kids, resentment could set in."),mdx("p",null,"It may be helpful to create a to-do list together and set a time limit on certain tasks. You may end up with a long list of chores, but at least you know what you need to do and what your partner should be helping with."),mdx("p",null,"Also, don\u2019t be a martyr. Even if your partner is working a lot of hours, you still have to do your fair share around the house, including taking care of the kids. You don\u2019t want to resent your partner just because they\u2019re working longer hours than usual."),mdx("h2",null,"Don\u2019t burn your dinner"),mdx("p",null,"This may sound silly, but it\u2019s important that you don\u2019t burn your dinner because you\u2019ve been rushing around trying to get everything done. You don\u2019t want to end up sick and tired because you\u2019ve been rushing around."),mdx("p",null,"Try to pace yourself and take some time to relax. If you have kids, try to give them a bath, play with them or read them a story before you start rushing around the house."),mdx("p",null,"Take breaks while you\u2019re working, even if you\u2019re not feeling stressed or overtired. You can take a break by going for a walk, taking a bubble bath or even meditating."),mdx("h2",null,"Take care of yourself physically and mentally"),mdx("p",null,"If both of you are always working and never relaxing, it\u2019s easy for both of you to become burnt out. Make sure you are taking care of yourself physically, like getting enough sleep and eating well."),mdx("p",null,"You should also be taking care of yourself mentally, which means not bottling up your feelings and letting them fester. If you and your partner are both working too much, it could cause resentment and anger. Make sure to share your feelings with your partner and open up about how you\u2019re feeling. Communicate with each other and don\u2019t let things build up."),mdx("p",null,"Taking care of yourself physically and mentally will help you avoid getting stressed out and will also allow you to be a better partner. relatedArticles.title: How to Make a Long-Distance Relationship Work
5 Ways to Cut down on Screen Time
How to Deal with Envy in Relationships

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Being in a new relationship is exciting and often feels like a whirlwind. You spend time getting to know each other and spending time together as much as possible. But things can change once you enter a committed relationship or get married. Stressors from work, family, friends and other responsibilities may arise, putting stress on your relationship. This is when green-eyed monster envy creeps in and can have a negative impact on your partner.
There are many different types of relationships: friendships, casual dating or serious partners. Regardless of what type of relationships you have with another person, envy probably won\u2019t be far behind if they are important to you. Envy is one of the seven deadly sins for good reason. When we experience envy in a relationship it creates distrust, resentment and can ultimately end things prematurely before they even really begin. However, there are ways to deal with this feeling so that it doesn\u2019t get the better of you.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 5 Ways to save Money as a College Student
How to Deal with a Partner Who's Always on Their Phone

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Now and again, your significant other will probably spend more time with their phone than with you. After all, it\u2019s 2018, and smartphones are practically a necessity for anyone who wants to stay connected. But if your partner is glued to their cell 24/7, it can obviously become a source of tension between you two. It\u2019s natural to feel a little jealous when someone you care about spends more time texting than talking with you, after all. And this is especially true if they seem to be ignoring you while they do so.
If your partner always seems to be on their phone, there could be several explanations \u2014 from an online affair to simply being an avid social media user. Regardless of the reasons why your partner might spend so much time on their phone, though, the way that you react definitely matters. Being insecure and accusatory about something as innocent as checking messages isn\u2019t likely to lead anywhere positive, after all. Here are some tips for dealing with a partner who\u2019s always on their phone:`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How the Pandemic Is Changing the Way We Work

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...n}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...n,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Time is money, as the saying goes. And when you\u2019re grappling with pandemic disease and a global outbreak, time spent at work has a whole different set of implications.
Pandemic flu strains have decimated human populations since the first recorded pandemic in 541 AD. Over the centuries, outbreaks have been frequent enough to instill fear in even the most stoic among us.
Today we face another pandemic threat with the potential to be even more devastating than those which came before it. A highly virulent strain of influenza A virus known as influenza pandemia has begun spreading rapidly throughout much of the world.
In many ways, today\u2019s workplace is very different from that of a century ago. Technology has advanced; office structures are more open and collaborative; and workers are expected to demonstrate self-motivation and flexibility in order to thrive in an ever-changing workplace environment.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: How to Beat the Winter Blues

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`The winter blues is a mood disorder that can affect anyone, not just people from northern regions. Symptoms of the winter blues are essentially SAD (seasonal affective disorder) brought on by the shorter days and colder temperatures of winter. If you find yourself feeling blue during the colder months but don\u2019t necessarily have a reason to be, you might have the winter blues. The good news is that you can combat this feeling with a little help from your friends and some lifestyle changes.
Whether you have or have had the winter blues in the past, there are ways to boost your spirits when those long, dreary days of January creep up on you like an old friend you don\u2019t want to see again. Here are some ways to beat those pesky winter blues and get back to your happy self!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 5 Tips for Eating Healthy on a Budget

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`Are you trying to eat healthier but find that healthy foods are expensive? Are you trying to make a good meal last for several days and not just one? Are you struggling to find affordable, healthy options near your home or work? If so, you\u2019re not alone. Eating healthy can be expensive and challenging. The cost of healthy food has gone up while the cost of unhealthy food has gone down. But this doesn\u2019t mean that eating healthy is impossible; it just means we all need to get a little bit more creative.
Eating well on a budget can be challenging, but it isn\u2019t impossible. Making smart choices about what you buy as well as how you cook your food can make a big difference in how much money you spend on food each month and how healthy your diet is at the same time.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 10 Easy Ways to Make Your Home More Energy Efficient

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...t}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...t,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`As the cost of living continues to rise, it\u2019s more important than ever for Americans to find ways to save money and stay within a budget. After all, no one wants to feel like they\u2019re drowning in bills every month.
To that end, everyone could probably stand to tighten their belts a little bit when it comes to their day-to-day expenses; after all, there are several small things we can do on a daily basis that will collectively add up and help us save money in the long run. In this blog post, we\u2019ll cover everything you need to know about energy efficiency at home and how you can start saving money by making your house more efficient today!`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

relatedArticles.title: 5 Ways to Make Your Mornings Easier

intro.compiledSource:
const layoutProps={},MDXLayout="wrapper";function MDXContent({components:e,...o}){return mdx(MDXLayout,{...layoutProps,...o,components:e,mdxType:"MDXLayout"},mdx("p",null,`You know those people who seem to get out of bed with ease every morning? You know, the people that you see on Instagram and wonder how they\u2019re so happy so early in the day? Well, we hate to break it to you but those people have their own set of problems. Getting up after a long night is hard for them too; the only difference is that their solutions work.
These people have their own rituals and habits when it comes to waking up in the morning. If these folks can do it then why can\u2019t we? It\u2019s because some of us are too comfortable, which means we need to shake things up! Do you want to be one of those people who gets out of bed with ease and has a productive day ahead of them? In this blog post, we\u2019ll tell you 5 ways you can make your mornings easier.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
